content:
The Act may be cited as the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define 'hydrographic data' as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. Hydrographic data includes information acquired through surveying methods like lidar, radar, remote sensing, geodetic, and geomagnetic measurements, tide, water level, and current observations, used in providing hydrographic services such as management, interpretation, and dissemination of bathymetric and shoreline information. Hydrographic services involve managing, maintaining, interpreting, certifying, and disseminating various types of hydrographic information, including nautical charts and databases. It also includes developing nautical information systems and related activities. The curr_chunk discusses nautical charts, databases, and nautical information systems derived from hydrographic data. It also mentions related activities and defines the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE ADMINISTRATOR. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892a) is amended to update authorities and responsibilities related to data gathering, dissemination, and hydrographic services to promote safe and efficient marine transportation. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to update authorities related to data gathering, dissemination, and hydrographic services for safe marine transportation. The Administrator may procure vessels, equipment, and technologies to ensure safe navigation and maintain expertise in hydrographic data. The Administrator may procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies necessary for safe navigation and hydrographic data acquisition. They shall design, install, maintain, and operate real-time hydrographic monitoring systems to enhance navigation safety and efficiency. Additionally, they may promote safe and efficient navigation where appropriate. The Administrator may acquire hydrographic data and provide hydrographic services to enhance navigation safety and efficiency, support conservation of coastal and ocean resources, and save and protect life and property. The Administrator may acquire hydrographic data and provide services to support navigation safety, conservation of coastal resources, and emergency response efforts for saving lives and protecting property. The Administrator may create joint centers with other entities to support hydrographic services for emergencies, disasters, homeland security, and maritime awareness needs. The Administrator can establish joint centers with other entities to support hydrographic services for emergencies, disasters, homeland security, and maritime awareness needs, as outlined in the Reform Act of 2006. The Hydrographic Services Review Panel is established under Section 4. The Hydrographic Services Review Panel, established under Section 4, consists of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator. The Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees serve as nonvoting members. Voting members are experts in hydrographic data and related fields. The Hydrographic Services Review Panel consists of voting members appointed by the Administrator who are experts in hydrographic data and related fields. Nonvoting members include the Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended. Authorization of appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions under sections 304 and 305, excluding hydrographic surveys, and for contracting hydrographic surveys including vessel leasing or chartering. Appropriations are specified for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. Authorization of appropriations for hydrographic surveys and operation of survey vessels for fiscal years 2009 to 2012: 
- $32,130,000 for 2009, $32,760,000 for 2010, $33,390,000 for 2011, and $34,020,000 for 2012 for contracting hydrographic surveys 
- $25,900,000 for 2009, $26,400,000 for 2010, $26,900,000 for 2011, and $27,400,000 for 2012 for operating survey vessels owned by the United States. Authorization of appropriations for hydrographic surveys, survey vessel operations, and geodetic functions for fiscal years 2009 to 2012:
- $32,130,000 for 2009, $32,760,000 for 2010, $33,390,000 for 2011, and $34,020,000 for 2012 for hydrographic surveys
- $25,900,000 for 2009, $26,400,000 for 2010, $26,900,000 for 2011, and $27,400,000 for 2012 for operating survey vessels
- $32,640,000 for 2009, $33,280,000 for 2010, $33,920,000 for 2011, and $34,560,000 for 2012 for geodetic functions. Authorization of appropriations for hydrographic surveys, survey vessel operations, and geodetic functions for fiscal years 2009 to 2012 includes funding for geodetic functions, tide and current measurement functions, and acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZED NOAA CORPS STRENGTH. Amends Section 215 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Officer Corps Act of 2002 to specify the number of authorized commissioned officers. Effective October 1, 2009, the total number of authorized commissioned officers in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's commissioned corps will increase from 321 to 379, subject to certain conditions including submission of ship and aircraft plans, availability of funding, and justification of organizational needs.
